Efficient and stable hydrogen evolution and antibiotic degradation in all-pH-scale water/alkaline seawater using Fe-Co phosphide hollow nanocages fabricated from metallurgical solid waste Zekun Zhao Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Visualization Supervision Software Resources Methodology Formal analysis Conceptualization a Suqin Li Writing – review & editing Supervision Data curation Conceptualization a ⁎ Yongkui Li Supervision Investigation Data curation a Qingqing Xia Supervision Resources a Haiping Lei Supervision Resources a Hao Zhang Supervision Investigation a Shuqiang Jiao Writing – review & editing Supervision Methodology Data curation Conceptualization a b ⁎ a School of Metallurgical and Ecological Engineering, University of Science and Technology Beijing, Beijing 100083, China School of Metallurgical and Ecological Engineering University of Science and Technology Beijing Beijing 100083 China School of Metallurgical and Ecological Engineering, University of Science and Technology Beijing, Beijing 100083, China b State Key Laboratory of Advanced Metallurgy, University of Science and Technology Beijing, Beijing 100083, China State Key Laboratory of Advanced Metallurgy University of Science and Technology Beijing Beijing 100083 China State Key Laboratory of Advanced Metallurgy, University of Science and Technology Beijing, Beijing 100083, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Fe-Co phosphide nanocages (FCP) prepared by selective etching of Fe-Co PBA and low-temperature phosphidation exhibit excellent hydrogen evolution performance in the alkaline seawater. The utilization of seawater, a plentiful and cost-effective resource, instead of freshwater for H2 production through electrolysis has garnered significant attention. Herein, we present the synthesis of open-structured Fe-Co phosphide (FCP) nanocages for the overall seawater electrolysis, employing metallurgical solid waste (steel rolling sludge, SRS) as the precursor material. The FCP nanocages demonstrate exceptional catalytic activity for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) in all pH scales, achieving performance comparable to that of Pt/C catalysts at high current densities. The electrolyzer assembled with FCP||FCP requires 1.57 and 1.68 V to achieve current densities of 10 and 100 mA cm−2, respectively. Furthermore, the assembled FCP electrolyzer showcases over 100 h of cycling stability and nearly 100% Faradaic efficiency. Crucially, it can be powered by commercially available silicon solar panels, operating under an intensity of 100 mW cm−2, and by wind-driven sources, rendering it highly promising for real-world applications. The seawater hydrogen evolution system coupled with levofloxacin (LEV) degradation was constructed for the first time. The oxidation potential of LEV oxidation reaction (LEVOR) was significantly lower than that of oxygen evolution reaction (OER), indicating that the LEV degradation reaction occurred preferentially and achieved a removal efficiency of 98.57% within 60 min. This study provides effective strategies for valorizing SRS and offers insights into the fabrication of high-performance catalysts. Keywords Metallurgical solid waste Fe-Co phosphide nanocages All-pH-scale Synergistic catalysis High current density Levofloxacin 1 Introduction With the depletion of fossil energy sources and increasing environmental pollution, the necessity for clean energy solutions, such as solar energy, metal-air batteries, and Li-ion batteries, has become increasingly evident [1]. Hydrogen (H2) stands out as the most promising clean energy source for addressing both energy depletion and environmental pollution in the future, owing to its abundant availability, excellent combustion properties, high energy density (120 MJ kg−1), and zero carbon emissions [2,3]. The electrolysis of water stands out as one of the most convenient and effective methods for H2 production, involving the direct splitting of H2O into H2 and O2 using electricity generated efficiently from renewable energy sources such as solar, tidal, geothermal, and wind energy. Notably, seawater resources surpass freshwater resources in abundance, making seawater electrolysis a key focus of current research [4,5]. Recently, due to the non-standard discharge practices of pharmaceutical companies, the concentration of antibiotics in seawater increased annually [6]. Levofloxacin (LEV), a widely used quinolone antibiotic, was one of these contaminants. High concentrations of LEV contributed to increased bacterial resistance and posed a threat to aquatic plants and animals [7]. Therefore, replacing the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) with the LEV oxidation reaction (LEVOR) to reduce its concentration in seawater was of great significance for marine environmental protection. However, the seawater electrolysis presents significant challenges owing to the abundance of Cl− in seawater, leading to undesirable chlorine evolution reactions (ClER) (Cl− + 2OH− → ClO− + H2O + 2e−) [8,9]. Therefore, there was an urgent need to develop new non-toxic, highly active, low-oxidation-potential, and cost-effective catalysts. Despite the excellent performance of advanced precious metal catalysts (e.g., Pt-based catalysts and rare earth catalysts) in the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) process, their limited reserves and high costs hinder widespread industrial use [10]. Hence, there is an urgent need to develop catalysts that are abundant, cost-effective, highly active, and possess low overpotentials. Transition metal phosphides (TMPs) are non-precious-metal catalysts that hold remarkable promise owing to their exceptional conductivity and high activity in the HER process [11–13]. They are applied widely in electrocatalytic H2O splitting for H2 production. TMPs such as FeP, MoP, Ni2P, and CoP are commonly employed as non-precious-metal catalysts in electrocatalytic processes [14–16]. Furthermore, TMP anode materials demonstrate excellent cycling stability, high reaction rates, and high reversible capacity. However, microstructure limitations significantly impact the electrocatalytic performance of TMPs. Hence, exploring innovative nanostructures holds great potential for diverse applications. Cage-like and framework-shaped nanostructures represent distinctive categories among complex nanostructures [17]. Compared to solid structures, open-channel structures facilitate full electrolyte-electrocatalyst contact while allowing the rapid escape of H2 generated from H2O splitting through open channels, thereby significantly enhancing HER performance [18,19]. For instance, Wu et al. developed Fe-Ni phosphide nanoframes with higher HER catalytic activity compared to Ir2O/Pt catalysts, attributed to their unique open structure [20]. In addition, Ji et al. demonstrated a CoP framework with a hollow structure, significantly enhancing HER performance compared to conventional hollow-structured catalysts [21]. Prussian blue analogs (PBAs) consist of face-centered cubic (FCC) unit cells bridged by cyanide ligands with transition metal ions [22,23]. They have garnered continuous attention owing to their excellent electron transfer properties, serving as ideal templates for preparing functional composite materials with specific microstructures, adjustable pore size, and surface area. Notably, during phosphorization, the cyanide group (CN) in PBAs transforms into N, P co-doped carbon layers encapsulating frame-like nanostructures, greatly enhancing material conductivity, stability, and catalytic activity [24]. Liu et al. fabricated defective cubic His-CuCoPBA catalysts and used them for selective lactulose degradation. They found that His-CuCoPBA can induce substrate binding and electron transfer simultaneously, thereby significantly enhancing the catalytic activity of the material [25]. Tao et al. synthesized NiSe2/FeSe2 heterostructure catalysts through the selenization of Ni-FePBA templates, achieving the overpotential of 230 mV at 10 mA cm−2, demonstrating excellent durability [26]. One of the factors hindered the large-scale application of electrocatalysts was the preparation cost. Currently, chemically pure reagents were commonly used to prepare electrocatalysts. The steel rolling sludge (SRS) was a solid waste from the metallurgical industry that urgently needed high-value utilization. Therefore, using it as a raw material to prepare electrocatalysts was highly significant. In this study, SRS was utilized as a raw material to synthesize Fe-Co PBA nanocubes. These nanocubes were then used as a template for the selective etching of open-structured Fe-Co nanocages, followed by low-temperature gas-phase phosphidation. This process results in the fabrication of a HER electrocatalyst known as FeCo-P nanocages (FCP), featuring a framework structure with a high specific surface area. Following phosphorization, the prepared FCP nanocages not only retain their original nanocage structure but also expose numerous catalytic active sites, promoting mass transfer. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations revealed a continuous decrease in the adsorption energy of the electrocatalyst for OH*/H* as the preparation progressed (Fe-Co PBA nanocubes → Fe-Co nanocages → FCP nanocages), enhancing the HER activity of the electrocatalyst in alkaline environments. Notably, the FCP nanocages demonstrated rapid mass transfer capability, a large electrochemical specific surface area, and excellent intrinsic activity, meeting the essential conditions for maintaining outstanding HER performance in environments with high current density. The FCP nanocages exhibited excellent HER performance in all pH values and alkaline seawater. Furthermore, continuous operation for over 100 h showed no significant activity decay, highlighting the excellent stability of the catalyst. Meanwhile, a seawater splitting system for hydrogen evolution coupled with LEV degradation was developed. The oxidation potential of LEVOR was significantly lower than that of the OER, demonstrating that the addition of LEV could reduce the energy consumption. Importantly, the composite system with FCP nanocages as the electrode could degrade hard-to-treat antibiotics while producing H2 through seawater electrolysis, thus achieving both clean energy production and marine environmental protection. This study not only achieves the effective utilization of SRS but also provides insights into the preparation of high-activity, low-cost electrocatalysts that meet practical usage requirements. 2 Experimental 2.1 Raw materials and analytical methods The SRS was collected from an iron and steel company. Its chemical composition and detailed morphology are shown in the Supporting Information (SI). The chemical reagents used are all analytically pure. Text S1 exhibits the details. 2.2 Synthesis of Fe-Co PBA nanocubes from SRS The pretreatment method for the raw material (SRS) is detailed in Text S2. In 50 mL of deionized (DI) water, 1.0 mmol of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, 1.2 mmol of L-ascorbic acid (C6H8O6), and 1.25 mmol of sodium citrate (C6H5Na3O7) were fully dissolved via sonication for 10 min. This solution is referred to as “solution A”. Separately, 0.7 mmol of potassium hexacyanocobaltate (III) (K3[Co(CN)6]) was dissolved in 50 mL of DI water by sonication for 10 min to form “solution B”. Subsequently, solution B was slowly added to solution A under magnetic stirring. After reacting at room temperature for 30 min, the mixture was allowed to stand for 24 h. The precipitate was collected by filtration, washed, and dried to obtain Fe-Co PBA nanocubes (Fe3[Co(CN)6]2). 2.3 Synthesis of Fe-Co nanocages To prepare the Fe-Co nanocages, 5 mL of NH3·H2O (28%) was diluted in DI water to a total volume of 20 mL (solution C). In 10 mL of anhydrous ethanol, 20 mg of Fe-Co PBA nanocubes was added and sonicated for 10 min to ensure complete dispersion (mixture D). Solution C was then added to mixture D and stirred magnetically for 18 min. The resulting mixture was filtered, washed, and dried to obtain Fe-Co nanocages. 2.4 Synthesis of FCP nanocages The FCP nanocages were synthesized using a low-temperature phosphorization method. A total of 20 mg of Fe-Co PBA nanocages and 318 mg of NaH2PO2 were placed in different positions within a ceramic boat (NaH2PO2 located upstream in the gas flow). The reaction occurred under argon flow with a heating rate of 2 °C min−1 and at 350 °C for 2 h, resulting in the formation of FCP nanocages. 2.5 Material characterization The analysis and detection methods are shown in Text S3. 2.6 Electrochemical measurements Details of the electrochemical measurements are shown in Text S4. 2.7 Theoretical calculation method Details of the Theoretical calculation method are shown in Text S5. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Material characterization In this study, the chemical elemental composition of the raw materials was provided in Table S1. Fig. 1 (a) illustrates the schematic diagram of the FCP nanocages synthesis process, which mainly consists of three consecutive steps. Firstly, Fe-Co PBA were synthesized using a precipitation method (The chemical equations involved in the preparation of Fe-Co PBA using SRS as a raw material can be found in the Text S7). Subsequently, Fe-Co nanocages were obtained using an NH3·H2O as a selective etchant and structure-directing agent. Furthermore, the final FCP nanocages were prepared through low-temperature (350 °C) phosphidation with NaH2PO2. The three-dimensional (3D) hollow structure of FCP nanocages, characterized by highly exposed active sites and open gas release channels, is conducive to enhancing its catalytic performance. The morphology of the prepared Fe-Co PBA was characterized using field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM). From Fig. 1(b and d), the surface of the Fe-Co PBA is smooth and uniform, with an average particle size of approximately 95 nm. The crystal structure and elemental composition of Fe-Co PAB were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD) and SEM-energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS). The XRD result displayed a typical PBA-type pattern with the face-centered cubic structure, and the SEM-EDS spectra confirmed the presence of Fe-Co combination in this PBA-type material (Fig. 1g and Fig. S1). The Fe-Co PBA was employed as precursors for the selective etching to prepare cage-like nanostructures. Specifically, treatment of the precursor with an appropriate amount of NH3·H2O for 18 min at room temperature resulted in the transformation of solid nanocubes into hollow nanocages. XRD and SEM-EDS observations confirmed that the Fe-Co nanocages obtained after selective etching possessed a cubic crystal structure and that their Fe/Co atomic ratio was almost identical to that of Fe-Co PBA nanocubes (Fig. 1g and Fig. S2). High-magnification field-emission SEM images of Fe-Co nanocages from different orientations are depicted in Fig. 1(c). The nanocages possess a cubic structure with an average particle size of approximately 100 nm, effectively inheriting the morphology and size of the Fe-Co PBA. The cavities at the vertices of the Fe-Co nanocages indicate their open structure. A closer examination of the microstructure of the Fe-Co nanocages reveals that they comprise six interconnected nanodisks, wherein each nanodisk serves as a supporting surface linking adjacent nanodisks, forming the 3D nanocage structure. The hollow structure and shape of the interior space of the Fe-Co nanocages were further investigated by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), as illustrated in Fig. 1(e). The TEM observations revealed highly uniform nanocages, consistent with the structures observed by FESEM. The unique internal space shape of the Fe-Co nanocages resembles a pyramid (Fig. 1f) with a central thickness of approximately 65 nm and a side thickness of approximately 17 nm on each side. The microstructure of the reaction intermediates obtained at different stages in the selective etching of Fe-Co PBA with NH3·H2O is depicted in Fig. S3(a). Initially, at 0 min of NH3·H2O treatment, the Fe-Co PBA maintains its nanocube structure. As the etching time extends to 6 min, there is no significant change in the surface morphology of the nanocubes, although the corners begin to show signs of etching. With etching time further extending to 12 min, noticeable cavities start to appear at the corners of the nanotubes, accompanied by the gradual hollowing out of their interior. As the etching time progresses, the cavities inside the nanocubes deepen and widen. Subsequently, when the etching time reaches 18 min, the eight cavities originating from the corners of the nanocubes coalesce at the center, resulting in hollow nanocages. Fig. S3(b) illustrates the internal and external structural changes of Fe-Co PBA as it transitions from nanocubes to nanocages. The etching process initiates from the corners of the nanocubes, gradually forming a hollow framework. Moreover, if the etching time is prolonged (30 min), the nanocages structure collapses, resulting in the formation of disc-shaped nanosheets (Fig. S4a). Substituting the anhydrous ethanol solvent in the etching reaction with H2O results in the transformation of nanocubes into nanosheets after 18 min of reaction time, indicating a faster etching rate in water compared to ethanol (Fig. S4b). Furthermore, the SEM-EDS analysis indicates that as the etching time increases, the Fe/Co atomic ratio of the catalyst remains almost unchanged (Fig. S5). From this analysis, it can be inferred that NH3·H2O facilitates the transformation of nanocubes into nanocages. Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) tests were then conducted on the intermediates of this series of reactions to determine the chemical composition under different reaction conditions. The FTIR results revealed that with prolonged reaction time, the characteristic peak intensity at 2117 cm−1 decreases gradually, while that at 2104 and 1605 cm−1 exhibits the opposite trend (Fig. S6). The characteristic peak at 2117 cm−1 corresponds to FeII NCCoIII, while that at 2104 cm−1 corresponds to FeII NCCoII [27,28]. This indicates that the etching process primarily occurs at the FeII NCCoIII site rather than at FeII NCCoII, attributed to the stronger affinity of CoIII for the CN group. Thus, the electron-donating ability of the N atom in the NCCoIII bond is weaker than that in the NCCoII bond. As a result, the binding of Fe(II) with the NCCoIII bond is weaker than that with the NCCoII bond, resulting in a higher susceptibility to etching at this site. The characteristic peak at 1398 cm−1 corresponds to NH4 +, with its intensity increasing with prolonged etching time, reflecting redox reactions during the process. Based on this analysis, the etching process may involve the following reactions [29]. (1) FeII 3[CoIII(CN)6]2 + 18NH3 → 3[FeII(NH3)6]2+ + 2[CoIII(CN)6]3− (2) 6[CoIII(CN)6]3− + 8NH3 → 6[CoII(CN)6]4− + N2↑ + 6NH4 + Based on the FTIR analysis, it is speculated that both the FeII NCCoIII and the FeII NCCoII bonds coexist in the Fe-Co nanocages, although their distribution may not be uniform. Specifically, the FeII NCCoIII bond appears to be predominantly located at the center of the nanocubes, whereas the FeII NCCoII bond is primarily found on the nanocube surface. The Fe-Co nanocages underwent phosphorization at 350 °C for 2 h to produce FCP nanocages. XRD analysis (Fig. 2 a) reveals that the FCP nanocages consist of a mixture of phosphides, primarily comprising CoP (PDF #29-0497) and FeP (PDF #39-0809). Furthermore, Fig. 2(b) shows that post-phosphorization, the FCP nanocages maintain the same structure as the Fe-Co nanocages, albeit with a rougher surface texture. Further examination via high-resolution TEM (Fig. 2c) reveals lattice fringes measured to be 0.192 and 0.181 nm, corresponding to the (2 1 1) crystal plane of CoP and the (2 1 1) crystal plane of FeP, respectively. To further confirm the presence of P defects, we conducted HRTEM analysis. Fig. S7(a) depicted discontinuous lattice fringes and the corresponding intensity profile (along the white dashed line in Fig. S7b), indicating the presence of defects. Energy spectrum analysis (Fig. 2d) confirms the uniform distribution of Fe, Co, and P within the nanocages. Additionally, static contact angle measurements (Fig. 2e) indicate that the FCP nanocages (26.59°) exhibit significantly smaller angles compared to the Fe-Co nanocages (37.65°) and Fe-Co PBA (46.87°). This difference can be attributed to the central cage framework structure and rougher surface of the FCP nanocages. A smaller static contact angle indicates higher hydrophilicity, which improves the affinity between the electrocatalyst and the electrolyte. This facilitates the enhanced contact between catalytic sites and the electrolyte, thereby accelerating mass transfer kinetics, particularly in the HER process [30,31]. The surface composition and chemical elements of the FCP nanocages electrocatalyst were thoroughly analyzed using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). As depicted in Fig. 3 (a), Fe, Co P, C, N, and O were detected in the FCP nanocages. The presence of the characteristic peaks of C and N is mainly attributed to the formation of conductive carbon nitride after the thermal decomposition of CN, which facilitates the HER reaction. The detection of oxygen binding energy suggests the surface oxidation of the electrocatalyst in the air during handling. In the Co 2p spectrum (Fig. 3b), CoP bonds are observed at 778 and 793 eV, while the peaks at 782 and 797 eV correspond to CoO bonds, indicative of catalyst surface oxidation [32]. Satellite peaks were also detected at 784 and 802 eV. Similarly, in the Fe 2p spectrum (Fig. 3c), the peaks at 706 and 719 eV correspond to FeP bonds, while those at 713 and 724 eV correspond to FeO bonds [33]. The P 2p spectrum (Fig. 3d) reveals peaks at 129 and 131 eV for the P 2p 3/2 and P 2p 1/2 states of the metal phosphides and at 134 eV for the P–O bond, attributed to surface oxidation [34]. Analysis of the N 1s spectrum (Fig. 3e) shows characteristic peaks at 402, 400, and 398 eV, corresponding to graphitic-N, pyrrolic-N, and pyridinic-N, respectively [35,36]. Furthermore, the C 1s spectrum (Fig. 3f) reveals four characteristic peaks at binding energies of 285, 293, 289, and 296 eV, corresponding to sp 2 carbon, sp 3 carbon, C–O, and sp 3 CN, respectively [37]. A deeper analysis of the XPS results indicates that the N content in the FCP nanocages is approximately 17.4%, derived from N-doped carbon originating from Fe-Co nanocages, which greatly enhances the overall conductivity and electrocatalytic activity of the catalyst. N2 adsorption/desorption experiments were conducted for the Fe-Co PBA nanocubes, Fe-Co nanocages, and FCP nanocages, with the resulting isotherms shown in Fig. 3(g). Notably, the FCP nanocages (247.8 m2 g−1) exhibit a larger specific surface area compared to the Fe-Co PBA nanocubes (95.4 m2 g−1) and Fe-Co nanocages (164.3 m2 g−1). Through electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) analysis, the specific defect types in the FCP nanocages and Fe-Co nanocages were examined thoroughly. The EPR spectrum (Fig. 3h) showcases a characteristic peak at g = 2.002 for the FCP nanocages, indicating the formation of specific P defects during the phosphorylation process. Moreover, with an increase in the dosage of the phosphiding agent (NaH2PO2) employed in the phosphorylation process, the intensity of the characteristic peak gradually increases (Fig. S8). These specific P defects promote the electron transfer rates, thereby enhancing the HER performance. Raman spectra were employed to analyze the Fe-Co nanocages and FCP nanocages, enabling further investigation into the graphitization degree of the electrocatalysts. The characteristic peaks at 1253 and 1435 cm−1 correspond to the D and G bands, respectively, attributed to defects in the catalyst graphite planes and the E2g vibrational mode of sp 2-bonded graphite carbon (Fig. 3i) [38]. The graphitization degree can be represented by the intensity ratio of the D and G bands (I D/I G). The detection results indicate that the I D/I G value of the FCP nanocages (1.27) exceeds that of the Fe-Co nanocages (1.04), demonstrating that FCP nanocages has a higher graphitization degree and therefore exhibits excellent conductivity [39,40]. 3.2 Electrocatalytic HER performance in all pH values Employing a typical three-electrode system with a 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolyte solution, we evaluated the HER performance of the Fe-Co PBA, Fe-Co nanocages, and FCP nanocages using linear sweep voltammetry (LSV), with commercial Pt/C (20% wt%) as a benchmark. In the acidic solution, compared to Fe-Co PBA (η 10 = 117 mV) and Fe-Co nanocages (η 10 = 87 mV), the FCP nanocages (η 10 = 62 mV) exhibited the smallest overpotential, demonstrating its superior HER performance. Moreover, FCP nanocages maintained a small overpotential even at higher current densities (η 100 = 104 mV, η 200 = 143 mV), which would broaden the application environment of the electrocatalyst (Fig. 4 a). The kinetics of the HER process was characterized by calculating the Tafel slope from the LSV curve. As shown in Fig. 4(b), the FCP nanocages had the smallest Tafel slope value, indicating that FCP nanocages possessed the highest HER catalytic kinetics. To thoroughly investigate the impact of solution pH on the electrocatalytic performance of the samples, we conducted tests in electrolytes with pH values of 3 and 5. As shown in Fig. S9, FCP nanocages maintained a low overpotential in all acidic electrolytes. In acidic electrolytes, the HER process includes three steps (Eqs. (6)–(8)). The Tafel slope value of FCP nanocages was close to 40 mV dec−1, suggesting that the reaction pathway most closely corresponded to the Heyrovsky mechanism. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) of Fe-Co PBA, Fe-Co nanocages, and FCP nanocages was further investigated. In the 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolyte, FCP nanocages exhibited the smallest electrochemical impedance, demonstrating that selective etching and phosphorylation promoted electron transfer and accelerated the electrochemical reaction (Fig. 4c). The multi-step chronoamperometry curve of FCP nanocages in the 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolyte is shown in Fig. 4(d). The current density remained stable with increasing potential, indicating that FCP nanocages has strong stability in acidic solution. (3) H3O+ + e− → *H + H2O (Volmer) (4) 2*H → H2 + (Tafel) (5) *H + H3O+ + e− → H2 + H2O (Heyrovsky) The electrocatalytic performance of FCP nanocages in a neutral environment was evaluated in 1.0 M phosphate buffered saline (PBS). The FCP nanocages (η 10 = 74 mV) exhibited the smallest overpotential in neutral solution and maintained the smallest overpotential even at higher current densities, demonstrating their excellent catalytic performance (Fig. 4e). The Tafel slope was calculated from the LSV curve, and the FCP nanocages had the smallest Tafel value, indicating that it still exhibited strong HER performance in neutral solution (Fig. 4f). Similarly, the FCP nanocages exhibited the smallest electrochemical impedance, demonstrating its excellent catalytic activity (Fig. 4g). The multi-step chronoamperometry curve of FCP nanocages in the 1.0 M PBS is shown in Fig. 4(h). The current density changed synchronously with the potential and remained stable throughout, suggesting its excellent stability. The LSV curves of FCP nanocages after continuous operation for 100 h are shown in Fig. 4(i). Whether in acidic or neutral environments, the LSV curves remained almost unchanged, indicating the excellent stability of FCP nanocages. In alkaline solution, the polarization curve and corresponding Tafel plot of the FCP nanocages reveal a 51 mV overpotential at a 10 mA cm−2 of current density (η 10), notably lower than that of Fe-Co nanocages (η 10 = 79 mV) and Fe-Co PBA (η 10 = 106 mV) (Fig. 5 a and Table S2). Furthermore, after NH3·H2O selective etching and low-temperature phosphorization treatment, the overpotential of the FCP nanocages decreased by 55 mV. This reduction was attributed to the enhanced HER activity of the bimetallic phosphides formed owing to the nanocages structure subsequent to selective etching. Actual production protocols imposed more stringent requirements on the HER performance of electrocatalysts, underscoring the importance of investigating the HER process activity at high current densities. Under high current densities of 100 and 200 mA cm−2, the FCP nanocages exhibited overpotentials of 97 and 132 mV, respectively, markedly lower than those of Fe-Co PBA (η 100 = 221 mV, η 200 = 273 mV) and Fe-Co nanocages (η 100 = 171 mV, η 200 = 214 mV). Meanwhile, the HER reaction kinetics mechanism of FCP nanocages was investigated by calculating the Tafel slope values of the electrocatalyst. Importantly, in alkaline environments, the HER process involves the generation of hydrogen via either the Volmer-Tafel process or the Volmer-Heyrovsky pathway. The specific reaction steps are as follows [41]. (6) H2O + e− → H* + OH− (Volmer) (7) H* + H*ads → H2 (Tafel) (8) H* + H2O → H2 + OH− (Heyrovsky) By reviewing the literature, it is known that the theoretical Tafel slopes for the above three reactions as determining steps of the HER process are 40, 30, and 120 mV dec−1, respectively [42]. In Fig. S10, the Tafel slope of the FCP nanocages is 55.4 mV dec−1, significantly lower than that of Fe-Co PBA (79.3 mV dec−1) and Fe-Co nanocages (66.9 mV dec−1), indicating that FCP nanocages undergo a typical Volmer-Heyrovsky reaction in the HER process [43]. These results from LSV and the Tafel slope values demonstrate that FCP nanocages exhibit superior HER performance compared to Fe-Co PBA and Fe-Co nanocages. In the electrolyte with a pH value of 9, the FCP nanocages still maintained a low overpotential, demonstrating its excellent electrocatalytic performance in all-pH-scale (Fig. S11). To examine the impact of different morphologies on electrocatalyst performance, we compared the HER performance of FCP nanocages with that of FCP nanosheets (etched in ammonia solution for 30 min). As shown in Fig. S12, the overpotential of FCP nanocages (η 10 = 51 mV) was substantially lower than that of FCP nanosheets (η 10 = 67 mV). This enhancement in HER performance was attributed to the nanocage structure, which provided larger catalytically active sites and facilitated the easier escape of generated H2. Conversely, the disc-shaped structure of nanosheets leads to stacking, resulting in the reduced catalyst porosity and hindrance to H2 escape. Notably, the strong interaction between phosphorization-treated bimetallic phosphides (FeP/CoP) at the interface induced electron redistribution and optimally adjusted the H* adsorption free energy at catalytic active sites [44]. Importantly, we prepared FCP nanocages using chemically pure reagents (FCPpure reagents nanocages) and compared the performance of FCP prepared from SRS (FCPSRS nanocages) as the raw material. From Fig. S13, the overpotential of FCPSRS nanocages is slightly lower than that of FCPpure reagents nanocages, indicating that FCP nanocages prepared from solid waste as raw materials exhibit excellent HER performance. This could be attributed to the doping of trace metal elements (Mg, Zn, and Al) present in the raw materials, which might have improved the lattice structure and enhanced charge transfer capability. Furthermore, the overall performance of the FCP nanocages synthesized herein surpassed that of some recently reported electrocatalysts (Fig. 5b and Table S3). As depicted in Fig. 5(c), FCP nanocages exhibited the smallest charge transfer resistance (R ct), indicating that the selective etching and subsequent phosphorization significantly enhanced charge migration, thereby improving HER performance [45]. The enhanced HER catalytic activity of the FCP nanocages was further investigated through electrochemical surface area (ECSA) detection. At scan rates ranging from 20 to 80 mV s−1, cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements were conducted in the non-Faradaic region of 0.0–0.1 V (vs. RHE) (Figs. S14–S16) to calculate the electrocatalyst double-layer capacitance (C dl). Notably, Fig. 5(d) revealed that the C dl value of FCP nanocages was the largest 5.03 mF cm−2, exceeding that of Fe-Co PBA nanocubes (2.37 mF cm−2) and Fe-Co nanocages (3.11 mF cm−2). This indicated that the open structure and phosphorization of the FCP nanocages provided an increased number of active sites for the HER process, substantially promoting the reaction. To further investigate the intrinsic characteristics of the electrocatalysts, ECSA normalization was performed on Fe-Co PBA nanocubes, Fe-Co nanocages, and FCP nanocages (Fig. 5e). Among all these electrocatalysts, FCP nanocages exhibited the highest HER activity, indicating that the advancement in the HER catalytic performance was attributed not only to the synergistic optimization of its open structure and phosphorization but also to the enlargement of its ECSA. To further explore the charge transfer dynamics of the catalyst, EIS tests were conducted at different potentials (0–0.18 V). The impedance of Fe-Co PBA increased with increasing potential, indicating lower charge transfer efficiency at high potentials (Fig. S17a). Meanwhile, the impedance of Fe-Co nanocages exhibited an initial decrease followed by an increase with increasing potential, indicating the restricted charge transfer at higher potentials (Fig. S17b). Importantly, the impedance of FCP nanocages decreased with increasing potential, indicating superior catalytic performance at higher potentials (Fig. S18). The Bode phase plots exhibited that with increasing potential, the characteristic peaks of FCP nanocages (Fig. 5f) shifted towards the lower frequency range and gradually decreased in peak value. The variation of characteristic peaks with potential demonstrated that FCP nanocages exhibited excellent charge transfer kinetics, which could greatly enhance operational efficiency and reduce energy consumption in large-scale industrial applications. Furthermore, the Bode phase plots of FCP nanocages, Fe-Co PBA, and Fe-Co nanocages at 0.18 V are shown in Fig. S19. Compared to Fe-Co PBA and Fe-Co nanocages, the FCP nanocages exhibited lower characteristic peak amplitudes and frequencies, demonstrating superior charge transfer kinetics and stronger adsorption capacity for *H2O molecules. This enables FCP nanocages to adsorb more *H2O during the HER process, thereby promoting subsequent H2O splitting into H2. To assess the HER activity of FCP nanocages in challenging real-world conditions, we tested their performance in both simulated (1.0 M KOH + 0.5 M NaCl) and actual (1.0 M KOH + seawater) seawater electrolytes. As illustrated in Fig. 5(g), the FCP nanocages exhibited sustained high HER performance in simulated seawater (56 mV), showing minimal deviation compared to a single-solute electrolyte (51 mV). However, their performance slightly declined in real seawater electrolytes (59 mV) owing to the presence of various impurity ions. These ions can be deposited on the FCP nanocages surface during the HER process, diminishing the available catalytic active sites [46,47]. Moreover, based on calculations, the Tafel slope values of the FCP nanocages in the three electrolytes were determined to be 55.4, 58.2, and 67.7 mV dec−1, respectively (Fig. S20). Concurrently, EIS revealed that with the increase in ion concentration in H2O, the solution resistance decreased (R KOH > R KOH+NaCl > R KOH+seawater). However, the charge transfer impedance of the FCP nanocages in the three electrolytes remained nearly constant (Fig. S21). This observation suggested that the FCP nanocages could uphold a robust charge transfer rate even in practical environments. To comprehensively evaluate the electrocatalytic performance of the FCP nanocages, Fe-Co nanocages, and Fe-Co PBA, OER performance tests were conducted. From Fig. 5(h), the FCP nanocages achieved 10 mA cm−2 with only 1.57 V, significantly outperforming Fe-Co nanocages (1.63 V) and Fe-Co PBA (1.72 V) in performance. At 100 and 200 mA cm−2, FCP nanocages still maintained excellent performance (1.68 and 1.75 V). Importantly, we thoroughly investigated the impact of catalyst loading on catalytic performance. The results showed that as the catalyst loading increased from 1 to 12 mg cm−2, the HER and OER overpotentials initially decreased and then increased (Fig. S22). With increasing catalyst loading, the number of active catalytic sites also gradually increased, which favored the catalytic reactions. However, when the catalyst loading was excessive, it led to aggregation, which hindered the escape of H2 and O2 and adversely affected the catalytic reaction. The corrosion polarization curves of FCP nanocages, Fe-Co nanocages, and Fe-Co PBA were tested separately in real seawater electrolyte to determine the seawater corrosion resistance of the electrocatalysts. FCP nanocages (−0.562 V vs. SCE) exhibited a higher corrosion potential compared to Fe-Co nanocages (−0.607 V vs. SCE) and Fe-Co PBA (−0.655 V vs. SCE), demonstrating its excellent corrosion resistance in seawater (Fig. 5i). The solution after the OER process was tested for ClO− using colorimetric method. As shown in Fig. S23, ClO− reacted with N, N-diethyl-p-phenylenediamine sulfate to form a red complex, with two strong absorption peaks at 510 and 550 nm. The solution after seawater electrolysis by the FCP nanocages electrocatalyst did not change color and exhibited no noticeable absorption peaks, indicating that no ClO− was produced. In-situ Raman spectroscopy detected the formation of hydroxides during the reaction. In Fig. S24, Fe-Co PBA, Fe-Co nanocages, and FCP nanocages all exhibited characteristic peaks at 681 cm−1, indicating the formation of Fe-Co hydroxide (FeCoOOH), which could serve as active sites for the catalytic reaction and promote the process. Compared to FCP nanocages, which produced FeCoOOH at the 10 min of the reaction, Fe-Co PBA and Fe-Co nanocages produced FeCoOOH at the 50 and 30 min, respectively. 3.3 Theoretical calculations and mechanism analysis To gain deeper insights into the outstanding HER performance of bimetallic phosphides, we employed first-principles calculations to unveil their unique electronic interactions and active sites. Initially, FeP, CoP, and FCP nanocages (FeP/CoP) structures were constructed on the (101) crystal plane, as this plane serves as the primary active surface for the HER process. This approach allows for a more detailed exploration of the interface effects of FCP nanocages on their catalytic activity [42]. Schematic diagrams of FeP, CoP, and FCP nanocages structures with (101) crystal plane exposure are presented in Fig. S25 from different perspectives. From Fig. S25(a amd b), it could be observed that FeP and CoP shared similar crystal structures, and the comparable electronegativity between Fe and Co, along with the appropriate crystal plane matching, contributed to enhancing regulation of the electronic structure at the interface. Based on DFT calculations, we simulated the process of H2O splitting into H2 on FCP nanocages in detail. In alkaline electrolytes, the HER occurs in two steps. First, H2O is adsorbed on the electrocatalyst surface and dissociates (Volmer: H2O + e− → H* + OH−), then followed by the splitting of H2O into H2 (Heyrovsky: H* + H2O → H2 + OH−) or the combination of two adsorbed H* to produce H2 (Tafel: H* + H*ads → H2). The Tafel slope value of the FCP nanocages (55.4 mV dec−1) indicated that their HER process was primarily governed by the Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism. Thus, we constructed a reaction model based on this mechanism (Fig. 6 a). Our calculations revealed that the rate-determining step of the HER process was *H2O → *[OH + H], with a 0.4 eV of free energy barrier (ΔG). In contrast, the ΔG values for Fe-Co PBA and Fe-Co nanocages were 0.82 and 0.61 eV, respectively (Fig. 6b). This suggested that selective etching and phosphorization successively promoted the Volmer-Heyrovsky reaction kinetics of the HER process in alkaline electrolytes. Fig. 6(c) showed the free energy of H* adsorption (ΔG H*) for FCP nanocages, Fe-Co nanocages, and Fe-Co PBA. A ΔG H* closer to 0 indicated a more favorable catalyst for the adsorption/desorption of H* [48]. The ΔG H* of FCP nanocages (−0.14 eV) was considerably lower than that of Fe-Co PBA (−0.63 eV) and Fe-Co nanocages (−0.38 eV), demonstrating that FCP nanocages possessed optimal active sites for the HER process. The density of states (DOS) of FCP calculated by DFT was depicted in Fig. S26. FCP nanocages exhibited strong metallic conductivity, primarily owing to the d orbitals of Fe and Co atoms being close to the Fermi level, which greatly enhanced the electron transfer capability of the catalyst. Additionally, we calculated the work functions of pure-phase FeP and CoP. Interestingly, when two materials with different work functions were combined, a potential difference was generated at the interface, leading to electronic structure adjustments and electron redistribution. The calculated work function of FeP (7.746 eV) exceeds that of CoP (7.573 eV), resulting in electrons transferring from CoP to FeP (Fig. 6d and Fig. S27). Furthermore, a literature review suggested that the binding strength of reaction intermediates was influenced by the surface electronic structure. Electronic structure reorganization at the interface optimizes the binding energy of the intermediate product H* [44]. According to molecular orbital theory, bonding and antibonding orbitals were formed by the interaction between H* and surface-active sites. Importantly, the higher the d-band position of active sites, the lower the filled antibonding orbitals, enhancing the adsorption energy of the catalyst for H* [49,50]. Conversely, the lower the d-band position, the higher the filled antibonding orbitals, thereby reducing H* adsorption energy. From Fig. 6(e), the calculated center of the 3d orbital d-band of Fe in FeP was located at −2.84 eV, slightly higher than that of Co (−3.17 eV). This indicated that Fe sites had a stronger H* adsorption capability than Co sites. The work function and DOS calculations revealed that the electronic structure adjustments and electron transfer at the interface enabled the catalyst system to reach equilibrium and exhibited catalytic activity far superior to that of the FeP and CoP phases. Fig. 6(f) presented the differential charge density of FCP nanocages, indicating strong electron transfer at the interface, which promoted the HER performance of the catalyst. After adsorbing H2O molecules, the adsorption site exhibited a high electron transfer rate, demonstrating that the reaction proceeded rapidly (Fig. 6g). The differential charge density slice diagrams of FCP nanocages and FCP-*H2O were displayed in Fig. S28, with electrons transferring from the blue region to the red one. The slice diagrams demonstrated that the heterojunction structure of FCP nanocages exhibited strong electron transfer at the interface. Moreover, the electron transfer rate would be further accelerated after adsorbing H2O molecules. Therefore, alongside selective etching and phosphatization, electronic restruction at the heterojunction interface was a critical factor in lowering the reaction free energy and accelerating the HER process. To delve into the local coordination environment of the FCP nanocages, the characterization was conducted using X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectroscopy. For Fig. 6(h), the Co XANES spectrum (K-edge) exhibited that the absorption edge of FCP nanocages was higher in energy compared to CoP, indicating a decrease in electron density around Co upon FCP formation, which was consistent with the results of DFT. Importantly, the pre-edge binding energy of Co in the FCP nanocages was higher than that of Co foil but lower than CoO, indicating that the oxidation state of Co lay between 0 and 2. The Co Fourier transform (FT)-EXAFS spectrum revealed that the oscillation peaks of FCP nanocages were similar to those of CoP, indicating structural similarity between FCP naocages and CoP (Fig. S29). Additionally, the oscillation peak of Co foil at 2.12 Å represented CoCo coordination, while the peaks at 1.64 and 2.58 Å for CoO represented CoO and CoCo coordination, respectively (Fig. 6i). The peak at 1.77 Å for CoP represented CoP coordination. Furthermore, compared to CoP, the CoP peak of FCP nanocages shifted negatively, indicating a decrease in Co electron density. During the HER process, the electron-deficient Co atoms could act as electrophilic centers to adsorb *H2O, which was consistent with the HER process calculated by DFT. Similarly, the Fe XANES spectrum showed that the pre-edge binding energy of FCP nanocages was lower than that of Fe2O3 but higher than FeP, indicating that the average oxidation state of Fe lay between 2 and 3 (Fig. 6j). The EXAFS spectra confirmed that FCP nanocages had a similar structure to FeP, and the oscillation peaks of FCP nanocages were entirely different from those of Fe foil, indicating that the coordination of Fe in FCP was significantly influenced by P (Fig. S30). Importantly, the oscillation peak of Fe foil at 2.43 Å represented FeFe coordination, while the peaks at 1.79 Å for Fe2O3 represented FeO coordination (Fig. 6k). The peak at 2.25 Å for FeP represented FeP coordination. Meanwhile, compared to FeP, the FeP peak of the FCP nanocages shifted positively, indicating an increase in Fe electron density. The coordination environment of atoms in FCP nanocages was investigated in depth by wavelet transform (WT). The maximum coordination strength of Co atoms in FCP nanocages was located at 5.8 Å−1, attributed to CoP band (Fig. 6l), while the maximum coordination strength of Fe atoms was at 6.2 Å−1, attributed to FeP band (Fig. 6m). 3.4 Cycle stability testing The cycle stability of electrocatalysts is crucial for assessing their viability in large-scale applications. We evaluated the cycle stability of Fe-Co PBA nanocubes, Fe-Co nanocages, and FCP nanocages using the potential method (current density of 10 mA cm−2). Notably, no significant change in overpotential was observed for FCP nanocages after 100 h of cyclic testing, whereas Fe-Co PBA nanocubes and Fe-Co nanocages exhibited considerable fluctuations in overpotential (Fig. 7 a). The polarization curve of FCP nanocages remained almost unchanged compared to the initial curve after 100 h of cyclic testing (Fig. 7b), indicating excellent long-term stability in alkaline environments. As shown in Fig. S31, after continuous electrolysis of HER for 100 h in acidic, neutral, and alkaline electrolytes, the current decay rates of FCP were 6.35%, 7.85%, and 5.26% at around 100 mA cm−2 and 6.68%, 3.97%, and 5.03% at 200 mA cm−2, respectively. No significant erosion was observed on the electrode surface, indicating that the FCP catalyst exhibited excellent stability. Importantly, testing at high current densities revealed its outstanding performance for practical applications. Notably, Fig. 7(c) demonstrated that the diffraction peaks of the cyclically used electrocatalyst corresponded well to the initial diffraction peaks, with no additional diffraction peaks detected, indicating that the FCP nanocages did not undergo a crystal phase transition. We further examined the microstructural changes of FCP nanocages after 100 h of cycling using TEM. While the microstructure of the electrocatalyst showed minimal change after cycling (Fig. 7d), TEM-EDS elemental mapping detected trace amounts of oxygen, indicating the partial oxidation of FCP nanocages during the HER process (Fig. 7e). The XPS spectrum did not exhibit any other characteristic peaks, suggesting that the catalyst maintained its original elemental composition (Fig. S32a). However, the increase in the O characteristic peak intensity suggested that the catalyst underwent partial oxidation reactions during the HER process. Furthermore, the Fe 2p and Co 2p spectra obtained after cyclic testing showed a slight increase in the FeO and CoO bond strength compared to that before the reaction, while the FeP and CoP bond strength decreased (Fig. 7f and g). This confirmed that a small amount of metal phosphide was oxidized to metal oxides during the HER reaction [51]. The increase in PO bond strength further indicated that the HER process was accompanied by oxidation reactions (Fig. S32b). The cycle stability of FCP nanocages could be attributed to the highly stable carbon nitride formed after CN pyrolysis, which coated the surface of FCP nanocages, preventing the dissolution of metal phosphides and crystal phase transitions [52–54]. 3.5 Investigation of overall seawater electrolysis The FCP nanocages maintained excellent HER and OER performance in seawater, so an overall seawater electrolysis system was constructed with FCP nanocages as the cathode and anode (FCP||FCP). With increasing KOH concentration, the overpotential of FCP nanocages decreased, indicating superior performance in high-concentration electrolytes (Fig. 8 a). This improvement was primarily attributed to faster interfacial kinetics and the stronger driving force of OH− in high-concentration electrolytes, which promoted faster H2 desorption and enhanced catalytic performance for the HER [55]. Additionally, as the electrolyte temperature increased, the HER performance of FCP nanocages also improved owing to enhanced mass transfer kinetics, which accelerated H2 release and increased reaction rates. Tafel slope values calculated for these systems indicated that higher electrolyte concentrations and temperatures benefited the electrocatalytic performance of FCP nanocages (Fig. S33). Similarly, the OER performance of FCP nanocages was improved with increasing KOH concentration and electrolyte temperature (Fig. 8b). Moreover, FCP nanocages underwent 100 h of cyclic testing in these electrolytes, with the current density remaining essentially unchanged (Fig. 8c), demonstrating excellent cycle stability in real and harsh environments. The Faradaic efficiency of FCP nanocages in 1.0 M KOH + seawater electrolyte was determined by collecting the generated gases. In addition, Fig. 8(d) and Fig. S34 exhibited that both the cathode and anode of the FCP nanocages electrode produced bubbles. The volume of the generated gas was calculated using the displacement method (Fig. 8e). The volume ratio (V O2:V H2) of the generated gases was approximately 1:2 (Fig. 8f), indicating that the Faradaic efficiency of FCP nanocages in 1.0 M KOH + seawater electrolyte was nearly 100% [56]. Finally, to further explore the practical application performance of the electrocatalyst, we integrated commercial silicon solar panels with electrolysis cells containing FCP nanocages, Fe-Co PBA nanocubes, and Fe-Co nanocages as electrodes, aiming to develop solar-driven water splitting systems (Figs. S35 and S36). Note that the red balloon expanded more than the blue and green ones (Fig. 8g), indicating the superior practical application performance of the electrolysis cell with FCP nanocages as electrodes. When sunlight intensity was 100 mW cm−2 (Fig. S37a), the current density of FCP nanocages reached approximately 16.3 mA cm−2, significantly exceeding that of Fe-Co PBA nanocubes (4.6 mA cm−2) and Fe-Co nanocages (5.2 mA cm−2). Moreover, its current density remained almost unchanged after 30 min of light-dark alternation (Fig. S37b). Wind power generation is the fastest-growing green energy technology worldwide [56,57]. In particular, abundant offshore wind resources and technological feasibility have made offshore wind power an important energy source in coastal areas [58]. Based on this, we constructed a wind power generation system in this study and utilized the generated electricity to drive seawater electrolysis reactions (Figs. S38 and S39). Note that the rapid expansion of the balloon demonstrated the successful electrolysis of seawater into H2 and O2 (Fig. 8h and Fig. S40). Therefore, FCP nanocages electrocatalysts exhibited exceptional HER performance and held promising prospects for extensive usage in future seawater electrolysis and new energy applications. 3.6 Seawater electrolysis coupled antibiotic degradation LEV was a common and difficult-to-degrade antibiotic, and its concentration in seawater had been increasing in recent years due to irregular discharges from pharmaceutical companies. Therefore, the FCP nanocages was used to construct a HER and LEVOR system with dual electrodes, and a bipolar membrane was used to separate the two reaction cells. The cathode electrolyte was 1.0 M KOH + seawater, and the anode electrolyte was 10 mg L−1 LEV + 1.0 M KOH + seawater (Fig. 9 a). As shown in Fig. 9(b), after adding LEV, the voltage required to reach a current density of 50 mA cm−2 decreased from 1.65 to 1.57 V, indicating that the energy barrier within the system was lower with the addition of LEV [59]. Additionally, the lower oxidation potential of LEVOR indicated that the degradation reaction occurred preferentially after the addition of LEV [60]. The EIS radius of FCP nanocages in the seawater + LEV reaction system was smaller, indicating that the addition of LEV increased the conductivity of FCP nanocages (Fig. 9c). As shown in Fig. 9(d), the composite system with FCP nanocages as the electrode exhibited the most excellent degradation activity, achieving a LEV removal efficiency of 98.57% within 60 min, significantly higher than that of Fe-Co nanocages (80.35%) and Fe-Co PBA (54.64%). The calculated degradation kinetic constant (k) of FCP nanocages (5.46 × 10−2 min−1) was significantly higher than that of Fe-Co nanocages (3.58 × 10−2 min−1) and Fe-Co PBA (1.96 × 10−2 min−1), demonstrating that FCP nanocages had the best application performance (Fig. 9e). The degradation process of LEV was further investigated using ultraviolet-visible spectroscopy (UV-Vis) spectroscopy. The LEV solution exhibited a distinct characteristic peak at 288 nm (Fig. 9f). As the reaction time increased, the intensity of this peak gradually decreased until it disappeared, indicating that LEV was decomposed from large molecular chains into small molecules and inorganic substances. We conducted continuous voltage measurements at a current density of 100 mA cm−2 to investigate the stability of the composite system. The oxidation potential of LEVOR changed little over a long reaction time, demonstrating that the system could operate stably for an extended period (Fig. 9g). Investigating the degradation performance of FCP nanocages on antibiotics (LEV) in real wastewater had significantly practical importance. Therefore, we collected real wastewater samples from a pharmaceutical factory in Shijiazhuang, China. The main component of this wastewater was LEV, with small amounts of ciprofloxacin (CIP), norfloxacin (NOR), and moxifloxacin (MOX) (Table S4). The overpotential of the catalyst for LEVOR (1.60 eV) in real wastewater was lower than that for OER (1.66 eV), indicating that the degradation of LEV was the preferred reaction. As shown in Fig. S41, the degradation curve of LEV demonstrated that within 60 min, the degradation rate of 10 mg L−1 LEV reached 91.4%. Although the complex components present in the actual wastewater somewhat inhibited the degradation activity of FCP, the degradation rate of LEV still remained above 90%, proving that FCP could be used as a catalyst for treating real wastewater. The FCP nanocages prepared in this study achieved efficient hydrogen production from seawater and antibiotic degradation. 4 Conclusions This study successfully synthesized open-structured FCP nanocages from metallurgical solid waste (i.e., SRS) and utilized them as catalysts for H2 production via seawater electrolysis coupled with the degradation of levofloxacin (LEV). The FCP nanocages demonstrated exceptional catalytic activity for the HER in all pH values, matching the performance of Pt/C catalysts at high current densities. Work function calculations indicated electron transfer from CoP to FeP upon their combination, supported by charge differential density analysis. This electron transfer and subsequent electronic structure adjustments at the heterojunction interface were identified as key factors enhancing the HER performance of the catalyst. The electrolyzer assembled by FCP||FCP demanded 1.57 and 1.68 V to achieve 10 and 100 mA cm−2, respectively. Furthermore, the assembled FCP nanocages electrolyzer exhibited cycling stability of over 100 h and Faradaic efficiency of close to 100%. The oxidation potential of LEVOR was significantly lower than that of OER, indicating that the LEV degradation reaction occurred preferentially, with a removal efficiency of 98.57% within 60 min. In summary, this study offers effective strategies for the high-value-added utilization of SRS and the preparation of high-performance catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The utilization of seawater, a plentiful and cost-effective resource, instead of freshwater for H2 production through electrolysis has garnered significant attention. Herein, we present the synthesis of open-structured Fe-Co phosphide (FCP) nanocages for the overall seawater electrolysis, employing metallurgical solid waste (steel rolling sludge, SRS) as the precursor material. The FCP nanocages demonstrate exceptional catalytic activity for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) in all pH scales, achieving performance comparable to that of Pt/C catalysts at high current densities. The electrolyzer assembled with FCP||FCP requires 1.57 and 1.68 V to achieve current densities of 10 and 100 mA cm−2, respectively. Furthermore, the assembled FCP electrolyzer showcases over 100 h of cycling stability and nearly 100% Faradaic efficiency. Crucially, it can be powered by commercially available silicon solar panels, operating under an intensity of 100 mW cm−2, and by wind-driven sources, rendering it highly promising for real-world applications. The seawater hydrogen evolution system coupled with levofloxacin (LEV) degradation was constructed for the first time. The oxidation potential of LEV oxidation reaction (LEVOR) was significantly lower than that of oxygen evolution reaction (OER), indicating that the LEV degradation reaction occurred preferentially and achieved a removal efficiency of 98.57% within 60 min. This study provides effective strategies for valorizing SRS and offers insights into the fabrication of high-performance catalysts.

coredata.dc:title: Efficient and stable hydrogen evolution and antibiotic degradation in all-pH-scale water/alkaline seawater using Fe-Co phosphide hollow nanocages fabricated from metallurgical solid waste
